entry.et: Middle English weder, from Old English; akin to Old High German wetar weather, Old Church Slavic vetrŭ wind

def.dt: :the state of the atmosphere with respect to heat or cold, wetness or dryness, calm or storm, clearness or cloudiness
:state or vicissitude of life or fortune
:disagreeable atmospheric conditions: as
:rain storm
:cold air with dampness
:weathering
:in the direction from which the wind is blowing
:ill
:drunk 1a
:to expose to the open air :subject to the action of the elements
:to bear up against and come safely through weather a storm weather a crisis
:to undergo or endure the action of the elements
:of or relating to the side facing the wind compare lee
:toughened, tanned, or bronzed by the weather a weather–beaten face
:worn or damaged by exposure to weather
:kept in port or at anchor or from travel or sport by bad weather
:a bureau engaged in the collection of weather reports as a basis for weather predictions, storm warnings, and the compiling of statistical records
:a deck having no overhead protection from the weather
:an eye quick to observe coming changes in the weather
:constant and shrewd watchfulness and alertness
:a map or chart showing the principal meteorological elements at a given hour and over an extended region
:a ship that makes observations for use by meteorologists
